description:
Candidatus Profftia tarda is a recently discovered and not yet officially classified bacterial species. It is considered a "Candidatus" species, which means it has been detected and characterized based on genomic data, but has not yet been isolated in pure culture or fully described.

The available information on Candidatus Profftia tarda suggests that it is an anaerobic, Gram-negative bacterium. It was first identified through metagenomic analysis of samples collected from a deep-sea hydrothermal vent environment. Phylogenetic analysis indicates that it belongs to the Deltaproteobacteria class, within the Desulfobacterales order.

Candidatus Profftia tarda is believed to be a slow-growing, chemolithoautotrophic organism, meaning it can obtain energy by oxidizing inorganic compounds and use carbon dioxide as its carbon source. Its genome suggests it may be involved in sulfur and hydrogen metabolism, potentially playing a role in the cycling of these elements in deep-sea hydrothermal vent ecosystems.

However, due to the lack of an isolated pure culture, many aspects of the physiology, ecology, and potential metabolic capabilities of Candidatus Profftia tarda remain to be further investigated and confirmed through future research.
